newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: SFE wheat up on Australia, Europe dry, U.S. frosts.
newsitem.headline: SFE wheat up on Australia, Europe dry, U.S. frosts.

text.p: Australian wheat futures moved sharply higher in nearer-term contracts on Monday on Australian European and U.S. weather concerns.

In Sydney Futures Exchange (SFE) floor trades, July 1997 jumped A$8.00 to A$196.00 on five lots and January 1998 rose A$1.00 to A$189.00 on two lots. Settlement prices also rose well with May and July 1997 both up A$6.00 and more distant contracts generally up by about A$1.00 a tonne.
Gary Booth of Ord Minnett Jardine Fleming Futures Ltd said SFE wheat's rise was on dry European and Australian weather and increased assessments of U.S. frost damage.
The Australian Wheat Board's continuing success in striking export deals for Australian wheat was against the background of continuing dry weather in Australia's southeast, Booth said.
Traders shorting the SFE market were forced to cover on Friday night, he said.
"The market's very positive. We continue to see wheat moving to resistance at US$4.86 (a bushel) December. The Sydney wheat contract now has a real chance of A$200.00 a tonne," he said.
He said hedging resistance should emerge at this level. "The difficulty is ... do we get the rain ... have they anything to hedge?".

Northern New South Wales (NSW) and southern Queensland had reasonable sub-soil moisture to plant on, but further south in NSW and into Victoria and South Australia conditions sharply worsened with not enough moisture to plant, Booth said.
Some areas had had record lack of rain although Western Australia had received good rain, he said.
"The market's simply waiting hoping we get sufficient rain to sow and get some sort of crop," he said.
There was still a few weeks to go before the real danger point but as time passed pressure increased on the domestic feed wheat market, he said.
